I'm going to get this out of the way.
Welcome to the 2016 Smithsonian Folklife Festival.
This year we're proud to present two exciting programs, Sounds of California and BASC, Innovation by Culture.
The Smithsonian Folklife Festival is produced by the Smithsonian Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage and co-sponsored by the National Park Service.
The Sounds of California program is co-produced with the Alliance for California Traditional Arts, Radio Bilingue, the Smithsonian Asian Pacific American Center, and the Smithsonian Latino Center.

Presenting partners include the Aga Khan Music Initiative, TUMO Center for Creative Technologies, and My Armenia, a collaborative project between the people of Armenia, USAID, and the Smithsonian Institution.

The program received federal support from the Latino Initiatives Pool, administered by the Smithsonian Latino Center, and the Asian Pacific American Initiatives Pool, administered by the Smithsonian Asian Pacific American Center.
Other supporters include the Sakana Foundation and Smithsonian Grand Challenges Consortia for the Humanities.
Radio Bilingüe presents a special coverage of Sonidos de California, a special program that is part of this year's Smithsonian's Folklore Festival.
This production is a collaboration with the Alliance for the Traditional Arts of California and the Smithsonian's Center for Folklore and Cultural Heritage.
I am Chelys Lopez.
Welcome.
During the next hour, we will talk with two impressive figures of Afghan music.
Exile and destiny have made them meet in the United States, in California, precisely.
This 2016, the festival offers diverse cultures united by migration, by movement and by that search for belonging.
Sounds of California and Basque innovation through culture are the two programs of this festival.
I have the pleasure of having on this table two magnificent musicians from Afghanistan, Salar Nader,
Welcome.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Salar is a virtuoso of the percussion instrument called tabla.
He is also a composer.
He was born in Germany and currently resides in San Francisco.
Humayun was born in Kabul, the Afghan capital, and is a master of the rubab, the national instrument of Afghanistan.
They both know how to combine their instruments, they know how to make them conversational on stage, achieving a delicious mixture of Afghan folklore with classical sounds of northern India.
So, welcome to all of you to Radio Bilingue en línea abierta.
Thank you very much.
Happy to be here.
So we understand that you have arrived here in part as a result of the war in Afghanistan and the areas there.
And the question that Chelise poses is, can you maybe talk a little bit about that experience and that story that brought you to the United States?
Sure.
So my parents left Afghanistan in 1979 during the time of
the Russian invasion of Afghanistan.
And so at that time, a lot of Afghans fled to either Pakistan, Iran, or West Germany, or actually West or East Germany.
And I was actually born in Hamburg in 1981.
So I only have stories.
of family members who actually fled during that time, family members who were imprisoned during that time by the communist government that took over after the monarchy.
And yeah.
Salar, his parents left Afghanistan in 1979, and he was born in 1981, so he only knows the stories that his parents told of what happened in Afghanistan.
That was during the invasion of the Russians in Afghanistan, that war.
Thank you.
What about you and I left Afghanistan 1992 Because was war in war and that's why I went to we went to shower And I was in the shower till 2001 and they came to us 2001
So, Humayun Saki left Afghanistan in 1992.
He was in Peshawar, Pakistan, until he arrived in the United States in 2001.
Now, both of you live in California.
I would like to know how you met, if you met in California, and how you decided to be musicians, to do this musical wonder that we heard yesterday.
And since you both live in California, and so Jelly's very interested in knowing how you both met and how you came together to make this beautiful, marvelous music.
Easy answer is destiny.
La constación es el destino.
Exactly.
Exactamente.
Actually, when he moved to Fremont, he established a music school, a school for rabab.
Homayun established a music school when he came to California.
Before we talk about the music school, I know you come from a family of musicians.
Did this influence you to become the musician you are today?
So you come from a musical family, Homayun, is that correct?
Exactly, yes.
My father is also playing the wabi, he's my teacher.
His father is also his teacher.
And also I want to teach and I want to share my music with everyone.
And when you arrived in the United States, specifically in California, did you listen to Afghan music?
So before you got to California, you heard in Afghanistan?
No, llegando a California si escuchaban.
Era facil que ellos escucharan la musica de Afganistan.
Oh, yeah, yeah.
Cuando llegaron ustedes a California.
Sorry, I do this all the time.
When you got to Afganistan, when you got to California.
Sorry, I'll get this right eventually.
When you got to California, was there Afganistani music in California?
Actually, yes.
There's a lot of Afghani people from Afghanistan and over, I think, 40,000, yeah.
And also my friends, they were there.
And that's why.
And the weather.
Actually, yes.
There were like 40,000 people from Afghanistan and there were musicians and their friends also in California.
And also the weather, he says.
That's something very important.

It was a very nice climate, but I should add to that because there are many vocalists, composers, singers, songwriters who fled in the late 70s and ended up in Fremont, California, or New York, or Virginia.
So it was kind of a reconnection of sorts with different artists.
And that's kind of how I grew up playing.
And I grew up playing in house parties, Afghan house parties.
I was five, six, seven years old.
And that was my first experience with Afghan music, because there was no international festival presenting Afghan traditional music.
And that's where I got my feet wet initially.
And that's actually how Humayun and I first met, the mafal style.
At the end of the 60s, many Afghan vocalists left Afghanistan and came to the United States, to California, New York, and Virginia.
Salar grew up playing, I mean, he started playing Afghan music at home parties.
And so, through playing in that environment, he met Humayun and other people.
Well, let's listen to some of the music of these two great figures of the music of Afghanistan, here in this special edition of Línea Abierta, from the Smithsonian Folklore Festival.

Well, we just listened to them, and I would like Salar to tell us a little bit about the instrument you play, which is the tabla, a percussion instrument, which is the only thing I know, and I know there are two different instruments.
Can you tell us a little bit about them?
Can you speak about the tabla a little bit?
And she understands there might be two pieces to this instrument and kind of fill people in a bit.
Sure.
So the tabla is a principal accompanying instrument of Afghan music, Indian music, Pakistani music.
And the tabla has its own language.
So every syllable that's played, every stroke that's played on the tabla has a corresponding note.
So on my left hand, you have na, ta, te, te.
And on the right hand, you have ge and kat.
So together combined, then you have compositions, like fixed compositions.
compositions we practiced, compositions that my ustad, my guru has given to me, Ustad Zakir Hussain.
So the style of tabla I learned was from Punjab, Punjab school of tabla, which is also prevalent in Afghanistan.
Ustad Hashim and his whole family also follow Punjab style.
So it's very interesting, this fusion of styles of tabla.
Basically, the tambor, or part of the tambor called tabla, is the main musical instrument that accompanies a lot of music from India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.
and it consists of two different drums, and there are sounds, that is, vowels, like syllables, that represent sounds in each drum, in each hand that the two drums are played.
And that's what Salazar was explaining.
And the biggest influence in his music is Punjabi music, that area.
And that's what he's explaining.
And there are compositions,
One more thing I would like to add to that is that to play with Robob, it's very special because you have to listen to a lot of Robob.
And Rabab music is very, very diverse.
Many styles, so many styles.
And Humayun plays all the styles.
Like any province, he can just go all night for you.
Like from one city to the next city to the next city, right?
He says it's very special to play tabla with rubab.
In Humayun, for example, there is a very diverse repertoire, and very local, that is, many repertoires or styles, local sounds.
And you have to listen, he says, to a lot of rubab music.

and especially to accompany Humayun, because he knows all the styles of all the places, so you have to know a lot to accompany Humayun Saki well, that was the tabla, now that Humayun tells us a little about the rubab, which is a kind of laud, it is also the national instrument of Afghanistan and we want to know a little more about it
Yeah, so can you tell us a little bit about the rubab, which is known as the national instrument of Afghanistan?
It is the national instrument of Afghanistan.
Yes, it is the national instrument of Afghanistan.
Can you tell us a little bit about the instrument, how it's played, or how it's put together, what it looks like, so people on the radio might be able to imagine?
Okay.
The rubab is made of... The rubab is made of mulberry wood.
The Rabab is made out of mulberry tree branch or root.
And it's three pieces of wood.
So you have the body, the neck, and the chest.
Like a fretboard.
And also skin, instrument is skin.
We are using the goat skin.
The goat skin.
And also on the wood you put the goat skin.
And also I have three main strings and two short arms, and 15 strings.
Two, three, and 15.
Three main strings, two short arms, we call short arms, like king strings.
And 15 sampete registrations.
Yeah, yeah.
OK.
Bien.
Y para las personas que están aquí y aprender un poco y los que nos escuchan en la radio, ¿escuchar música de Afganistán tradicional es necesariamente el rubab y la tabla?
¿O es algo que ustedes adoptaron?
Ah, la música.
The music from Afghanistan is specifically what you do, the two instruments together?
Or is this something that you have really elevated as your style?
Actually, we have a lot of different... We have a mahali, we call mahali sos logari.
And that's like four people, they are playing together.
Mahali is the name of the group?
Mahali is the name of the style.
So, mahal like for the people, music for the people.
And that's usually a four-piece ensemble.
Four-piece ensemble, yes.
The style of music is like music for the people, you say?
And also we have different instruments, like tambour, dutar, tambura, zirbagali.
This is mahali.
So there are tambour.
Otro es el dotar, y otro es tambura.
Tambura.
Tambura.
And the fourth one?
Zirbagali.
Zirbagali.
Zirbagali, which literally means underarm drum.
Ah, y un tambor que se toca debajo del brazo.
Y esta pregunta quizás es un poco boba, pero ¿se tienen que tocar sentados?
This might be kind of a silly question, but do you have to play sitting down?
So, yeah, traditionally these instruments are played, they're most comfortable sitting down.
Like, Humayun has made a rabab that he can play standing up, but... That's a rock rabab.
That's a rock rabab.
He says yes, normally you play the instruments sitting down because it's much more comfortable.
But Humayun invented a type of rubab that you can play standing up, but he says that rubab is for rock and roll.
Actually, because I started when I was 10 years old.
But at that time, people said, you know what?
This is not for young people, this instrument.
But this instrument is for other people.
And that's why I said, you know what?
I have to play for a young generation.
And also, I have a question.
Right now, I have more than 60 students.
They are all young.
They are just like 15, 14, 18.
More than 60, yeah.
He says that he currently has more than 60 students and many are young, like 15 or 16 years old.
That is something important that I would like to explore more with you.

How about the children, the young people, you already mentioned it more or less now, but how much are you doing to follow the tradition and of course maybe incorporate a little, as you mentioned, instruments that are more for young people or maybe sing in English too, mix the pastun, I don't know, the languages.
OK.
In short, you mentioned how there's this sometime perception of age difference.
What are you doing to, are you doing anything special to involve young people in this music?
For example, she says, do you ever put any English words or any other musical influences into your music to attract young, to appeal to young people?
I mean, let me, let me, myself, as a Jawan and as the Jawan,
What did you do that made them want to participate more?
Some songs, like new songs I was playing that time, that was like, people, they sing like this is not coming, like this is people was not playing on the rubab.
And that's how I was playing that songs for young people.
And that's why, like, the young generation, they said, oh, you know what?
You have to play rubab.
He said that in his Rubab instrument he played melodies that were for young people, and he said that this music is also for young people, so that they know that this music was for them too.
Yeah, I was playing it like Gypsy King on the ruban.
And I said, oh my God, this is coming on ruban?
This is... Like Gypsy King was playing music, to show that his instrument could also play music for young people.
And young people could play any music they were interested in on the ruban.
Yeah.
And that's what we heard last night in the concert, some of those sounds.
Thank you.
Combinations.

And as part of the two programs of the Smithsonian Festival this year, California Sounds, I understand that you have collaborated with, for example, the Cronos Quartet, which is also impressive in terms of its genre, its style, if I may say so.
¿Qué tanto les han aportado a ustedes, los músicos de California, para continuar con la música de ustedes de Afganistán, pero a la vez abrazar los sonidos de California?
So we're in this program in the Folklife Festival this year, Sounds of California.
And so the basic question is, you've collaborated with Corona's Quartet, for example, a very successful collaboration.
And in the ambience of California, have you worked into how have you embraced the sounds of California that you hear around you in your music at all?
Have you involved that in your music?
OK.
All right, I'm going to try to answer this.
A lot of pressure on me right now.
Yes, California has had an influence on our music.
We play a song called Hotel California.
Actually, it sounds amazing on the ruban, really.
I should say, all jokes apart, that what's really important, although we're living in California and we're embracing and assimilating, is we're hanging on to our roots and our culture.
California is going to benefit from having Rabab.
rather than the rubab player start playing all Californian tunes, I think.
It's a great time.
It's a great time to be in California.
You have Homo Insahi there, you know.
There's thousands of guitar players.
There should be more people taking up the rubab, I think.
It's an exceptional time to sow this music because there are thousands of guitarists and there has to be people who will play the rubab more.
So you venture into these new sounds of California.

Do you have in mind any place, any stage where you have reached, that you have perceived at the moment, new audiences, new places that perhaps you did not imagine, and that is perhaps thanks to the fact that you are in California, that you live or are residents of California?
I mean, like big events where a lot of people came?
A place where they did not imagine bringing the music of their country.
So in the context of California, are there any places you ended up playing that you never expected to play in your entire lives?
Contexts, events, community settings, anything?
Like really interesting.
Actually, for me, everywhere is interesting.
I'm playing like, you know, because you're playing somewhere that's new, you know, it's
It's interesting.
But if the question is, what's our most interesting night in California?
Or interesting venue to play in California?
Yeah, taking the Afghanistani music to some interesting setting.
Well, OK.
I'm just going to use yesterday as an example.
You have a brand new audience, like Omarion said.
They've never heard this music before.
They've never seen the instruments before, rarely.
And we have 60 minutes or 45 minutes or 25 minutes to engage the audience and hope that they walk away feeling better and more positive.
And the language that we speak might be completely foreign.
But the sounds, rhythms, melodies are universal.
And that's what we're basing everything off of.
And I think and I hope we've had pretty positive results.
The concert last night here at the festival is an excellent example.
They were playing.
They have 60 minutes, 50 minutes, 25 minutes to bring the sound of their music to a new audience.
and is a good example of the most interesting events for them, the most impressive for them when they have played their music, for example, here at the festival.
Well, for my next question, I would like our audience to listen to the following that was recorded yesterday at the concert here at Paseo Nacional in Washington, DC.
So now they're on the radio.
They'll be playing excerpts from last night's concert.
That's what we're doing right now.
Oh, nice.
Thank you.
In this space.
I hope people will like it.
Well, what we just heard was the collaboration you had yesterday with Kepa Junquera, this musician from the Basque Country, and with Enerix, the girl from El Pandero who accompanied him.

I would like you to tell me a little about that experience of sharing with a musician who... There was no interpreter, I understand, inside the stage or above the stage, and yet you made the sounds, the instruments,
So yesterday was an interesting combination with the Basque music, with the accordion, with the tambourines and all that.
And she was fascinated and she knows a lot of other people were fascinated.
But how did you feel about that?
Are there words that can describe what you felt in that experience?
When I play with any new artist or a new collaboration, the initial step we take is a conversation, always positive, and we feel good about meeting each other and sharing a new dialogue.
So when they play for the first time with a new artist for them, everything starts with a conversation, something positive, talking to them, exploring what they will be able to do.
And last night was without practice, without anything, just they came on stage and that's it, played together.
And the concert last night was without rehearsal, without anything, they just got to the stage and played together, and that's it.
It sounded like you had rehearsed all of your lives.
And there was singing in the concert last night as well.
For example, the Basque singer.
Did you have any idea of what she was singing about?
Actually, no.
Just the music was really good.
She knows what the bass singer sang, but she has no idea what you sang.
What did you sing?
That's a big secret.
If you tell us what she was saying, we'll tell you what we were saying.
So she wants to know what was actually coming together there on the stage.
The song was a love song.
I don't know in English, but okay.
So I'll take one line at a time.
So Laili, Laili, Laili Jaan.
Laili is a name of a woman and whoever composed this definitely composed it for
Layli, our version of Roxanne.
And then that's the first line and the second line.
You're killing me.
Armón is like your... I hope to see you waiting.
It's longing and waiting for Lely John.
You're sending her a text message and she's not responding.
Like today, they sent a text message and she doesn't answer.
It's the pain she feels.
Well, I'm going to tell you what Enerix sang yesterday on stage.
She told a story of a young woman who leaves because her parents send her to become a nun.
And she decides to escape, return to the city or her town, get married and have children with a traditional family.
So the song, the bath song, spoke about how the parents sent their daughter to study to be a nun, basically.
A sister, you know, of the church.
And then she came back.
And she got married.
Then she came home.
Eventually she got married and the whole thing, had children, the whole business.
Well that's awesome.
But she didn't remember what she had sung.
She said the second song she couldn't didn't remember what she sung because she was so nervous at the time.
So that's all that's all so she couldn't tell her what it was.

So if anybody has a question for our invited artists here, Humayun Saki and Salah Nader, now from California, Afghanistan background, great musicians, both of them, this is your chance to ask questions.
Yes, we have a question back here.
This is for our radio audience.
When you collaborated with the Kronos Quartet, did you introduce new instrumentation to their oeuvre, to their repertoire?
Did you introduce, for instance, the Afghan instruments?
Yes, actually, Kronos Quartet, actually David, he called me.
He called me one day, he said like, you're from Afghanistan and you're playing an instrument, Rabab.
I said like, yes.
And he said like, can you compose for Kronos Quartet?
I said, of course, why not?
And at that time, I was just, this is like the sound, and also true of Aga Khan in E. It was endorsed, sponsored.
Sponsored, but yeah.
And after that, I composed for Corona Squad.
So the question was if, in collaboration with the Kronos string quartet, if they had introduced the instruments of Afghanistan, etc.
And Humayun says that he called David, who is one of the main members of the Kronos quartet, and asked if he played the robab.
He said yes.
So it turned out that he composed music to play with the Kronos quartet.
And also the name of the compose is Rangin Kaman, we call it Rambo.
And why I put the name Rambo, because I choose from each village of Afghanistan.
The compose is new, but I choose from north, south, everywhere, and I
Not Rambo.
No.
He did save Afghanistan in Rambo 3.
Any other questions?
Yes.
Can you talk about things that you've seen you have in common with people in California, maybe the Mexican influence there or the people from Mexico that you feel like the cultures have in common?
Well, I mean, we all have a common interest in good food.
We get really good avocados in California.
Hawaiian and I love it.
And also the music.
The music is very close.
You know, Afghani music because some melodies are very close.
The scale, you're using that scale also in Afghanistan.
We are using that scale.
Sometimes I'm playing bass.
Yeah.
Go on.
Another common interest we have outside of the music is that we all love football, soccer.
So there's a massive soccer tournament, Afghan soccer tournament that happens every year.
And then it's mixed.
We also have visiting players from Mexico who we actually pay to play on the teams.
It's kind of like...
Yeah, because we need like some football stars.
And Omoyin and I, we always go and attend.
So you'll find us in the audience, and we just love it.
So.
And also I love ceviche.
Mexican, yeah.
Mexicano, ceviche mexicano.
Well, let's continue, of course, opening the microphone so that you can ask your questions.
But I would like to know what you perceive of the new generations of the community of Afghanistan in California.
Especially in Fremont, we said that it is where there is more population, but are the young people connected with the music, with the traditional music of Afghanistan?
What's your impression of young people of Afghanistan descent in California, like in Fremont for example, where you lived for a while anyway.
What's their, how do they see the music?
Are they coming to the music?
Are they becoming part of the music making and appreciation?
Actually, yes.
Now they are playing tabla, rubab, and they are singing.
They are very interested.
That's why I have a school in there.
and teaching and people they're coming the kids see it's it's it's a really important time that we're living in right now as afghan americans being in california and

What Humayun is doing, because he's in the north, I'm in the south, and we have completely committed ourselves 150% to keep the music original, authentic, so that the next Afghan generation that is born here in the States has some type of connection to their roots.
Because we cannot lose that.
That's the last thing we have.
And it's very, very important.
So if you're listening to this radio interview and you happen to be Afghan-American, or not Afghan, and you're interested in Afghan culture,
Look up Hawaiian up north.
You can take vocal classes with them.
You can play to Bob.
And he's doing a massive service to the community and for the next generations, you know, 30, 40, 50 years from now, we're not going to be here.
And we have to leave something behind.
This is a very, very important time in history for the people of Afghan origin in California.
Because now what they are doing is trying to leave the living root of the music, of the culture of Afghanistan in the United States.
And in 40 and 50 years they say that maybe they will not be here, but they want to leave their legacy.
so that new people, whether they are Afghans or non-Afghans, can come to music to learn the tradition.
Well, it's important and I appreciate that you, being young, are doing this work so that the other younger generations continue with the tradition and the belief in the music of Afghanistan.

But what about those who you learned from, apart from your family, of course, the grandparents, the older people of Afghanistan who live maybe in Fremont or in all of California, and who are musicians?
She says she appreciates that young people like you are carrying on this tradition.
But what have you learned yourselves from other Afghanistani people in California?
Older people, older people, yeah.
Are there things that you've learned from older people of Afghanistani descent in California?
Have you played with older musicians, for example?
In California.
In California, yes.
I don't know.
He doesn't know.
He has to think about it.
You're saying like Afghani.
Yes, yes, yes.
I was playing with... His name is... Aziz Erabi.
Oh, Aziz Erabi, yes.
He has played with Aziz Erabi.
Yes, he has his album in Arjul and I remember those things.
So what do you need to do to live in these modern times, 2016, and not disconnect from the past, which is a little bit like what you were describing there.
eat a lot of ceviche.
What do we need to do to maintain?
Well, we wake up and you can never kick the Afghan out of the Afghan.
No matter what you do, we maintain our language.
We speak Farsi and Pashto.
we cook our traditional foods, we pray, we maintain our spirituality, and we have our families, you know, thank God, the blessings.

We've been very lucky and fortunate to have a second home outside of Afghanistan in California where, you know, we have our communities and we're maintaining, like I said again, maintaining our roots, evolving with the times, but still maintaining our roots and open to collaborating,
all of it, but at the same time just reminding ourselves where we came from, how hard our ustads worked to give us the knowledge.
His father, his grand guru, Ustad Madomar, who also came to the States in 1974, and
You know, these are quick times, social media, viral videos, and you could really lose yourself in this.
When they wake up every day, they live their life as Afghans, because you can't take the Afghans away from the people of Afghanistan, right?

and we also live in a situation here in California, for example, that he learned from his grandfather, and we are in this time of social media, right, that can be lost in social media, but they practice their spirituality, their food, their family life, all the traditions, that is, they live life
And I just want to add one more thing is that, Humayun, you go back to Afghanistan, right?
Like, two, three times a year.
Yeah, so no matter what's happening or what you see in the media that's happening in Afghanistan on a daily basis,
we actually still go back, we go back together, we're actually planning on going back in October and we teach music there.
Umayoun's 60 students that he's mentioning, I just want to kind of add this, those are 60 professional recording concert playing musicians.
That's not to mention the hundreds of others that are just studying, right?
And they were saying that, first of all, the students, the 60 students that Humayun mentioned, are at a professional level.
And also, there are like hundreds of other students.
And despite what is being told today in the media, on television, in whatever,
Do you like track and field?
I love track and field.
I was born in Afghanistan, they still have track and field there.
The Afghanistan track and field, track and field by itself, Olympics with support of Arzish.
They love it.
Yeah.
You know, I should also mention that Omayun, growing up in his teenage years, he's told me while we're on tour, traveling, you know,
You're on the road with each other for a month, in each other's face every day, on stage, so it's like news stories, what are we going to talk about?
And at one time, Humayun liked martial arts, like Bruce Lee, Taekwondo.
I mean, no, really.
So watch out.
Be careful.
We have time for one more question here, please.
How do you promote Afghan music in America?
How do you keep it alive?
I heard you talk about growing up with house parties, right?
And I suspect there's some attraction in festivals, right?
But does it play well in clubs in American club style settings?
How do you promote it?
Yeah, it's really tough.
It's really, really tough.
And this is something we deal with on a daily basis.
I mean, we're living in the time of Justin Bieber and boy bands, and that's never going to go away.
